commentBody: I think this is a perfect example of  Wednesday puzzle.

My cat plays "The Floor is Lava" (or, perhaps, The Floor Is Dog) by using my body as a bridge. 

Usually I see his jumps coming...

Very nice Wednesday puzzle. Had to read the article to understand a short first step = atob(?)=a to b. Got it with downs but was afraid I had something wrong. I did, I spelled Eudora Welty as Welty. Easy fix. Had Cal for mo setting until I realized eyeaore didn’t work. So thought outside the box and came up with CST which also made me realize “decorated” a house for Halloween was not Lped, but Teepeed. Bested my average by over 2 minutes
Blah theme featuring a lot of insipid fill. Shoulda been a Monday. I liked the geography clues though.

So, it's news to me that "The Floor is Lava" is a new game. I remember playing at a kid in the late 60s (possibly early 70s) but I'm pretty sure it was in the 60s. I played it at my godfather's house with his kids. He and his wife wondered what was happening to their doorknobs because we had used them to stand on to swing on a door from one place to another (bed to dresser for example).

Wow I guess I (and my kids) had a deprived childhood because I never heard of this or played it. Fun idea though. Nothing wrong with this puzzle, but Monday or Tuesday level IMHO both in theme and difficulty.
A quick solve, until I got bogged down in the long HAuL.  Anyone else?

Said one volcano to another, "You magma my dreams come true!"

(I'd post this one sooner or crater.)

I kept juxtaposing visions of the chalked outline of my streak, police tape, and the bottom left corner of the grid. Somehow I got through it, but man, those clues were devious. Thanks, Eli, for the workout, and a brief reprieve from the woes of the world.

Yikes. A lot of bad crossings here. No idea what the pun for Long HALL is supposed to be, nor what an ELO is. HAuL would have made sense for that clue, and EuO was just as plausible. I suppose I'm fortunate to not have to know what _GEL was, but would have needed 26 guesses to guess what it crossed with WEL_Y.

I was only slightly more confident in OPART/APU than I was in potentially AbU/ObART.

At the risk of being that guy: TGEL crossing WELTY is a textbook example of a natick, right?

With that said? A fun and breezy puzzle. I for one don’t mind the occasional proper noun collision.

Our game, circa 1965, was Blind Man’s Buff played in a dark interior long HALL of our house with all the doors closed. Usual rules about being “It”. If not “It”, a good hiding technique was to use both arms and legs to shinny up one of the door jambs, and cling there near the ceiling.
Same hall made an excellent venue for vigorously slamming around the latest new thing, the Super Ball. We may or may not have broken a ceiling light fixture that way.
WORTH IT!
These memories brought to you indirectly thanks to the lava theme.

THE FLOOR IS ____ must have once been a clue for LAVA in the NYT crosswords. I have no other explanation as to why I knew the name, seeing that I've never heard of it nor played it. And I didn't have the slightest idea as to how it's played before reading the column. Well, ignorance is bliss – I might not be alive today if my parents had ever caught me and my siblings hopping onto a table, standing on the kitchen counter, or jumping onto a couch. I'm almost inspired to play THE FLOOR IS LAVA right now to make up for lost time, but the apple doesn't fall far from the tree and I don't want anyone jumping around on my table, counter, and couch. The only question that remains now is what on earth is SST? Grateful if someone would explain. I was so sure that bygone initials at JFK would be TWA. Is it not JFK airport we're talking about? Lastly, here are Sonny and CHER singing "I GOT YOU, Babe"... https://youtu.be/r5fFlI7MFeM?si=b7CzDwc4UWFfA5IO Thank you for this charming puzzle, Eli!

Can someone explain what on earth an “atob” is? or… a tob? at ob? ato b? a t o b?

I completed the puzzle on crosses… searched this after I finished and the only thing that came up was javascript. if these crossword assemblers want me to know javascript you gotta be kidding me.

Now that I think about it, I'm going to need someone to explain 47D [Long way to go?].  

How is it HALL?  Because it's a homophone of HAuL?
Enjoyed the puzzle overall but 53D/63A was a full alphabet natick for me
I do believe these theme answers are the most clever set in recent memory. Slightly clunky fill, but well done Eli!

Loved the nostalgia this puzzle brought up. My brother, sister and I played THE FLOOR IS LAVA all the time as kids, especially when it was time to pickup our toys. I’m sure my parents had no idea since it was a babysitter that taught us the game 😆 I DARE NOT recommend playing this while wearing Jimmy CHOOs!! However, listening to Don’t Bring Me Down by ELO while playing would be WORTH IT. Enjoy! https://youtu.be/z9nkzaOPP6g?si=LiC_wRa4RQvIqtye Thank you for this fun romp, Eli!

Overheard in a posh hotel. The PREFAB Four havin a chat after their Get Up and Go show:

Stig fancies a dance with BACCHUS and JABS at Dirk. "ELO, ELO, ENUF of that GLUMMER. How's about a DRAM, or some mull of Kintyre?"

Dirk is having none of it,  "We USED to be mates. Now IDARENOT pluck a chord, as you're LIABLE to ride HERD over me like ADOLPH at a TEDTALK in Hamburg.

Stig turns to Nasty. "WANNAGO?" 

 "NOCANDO, muzak man, Nasty replies. He slips out WIT OSAKA for the opening of "WOOSH," their OPART EYESORE featuring SST brake ROTORS.

Stig looks over at Barry, who has managed to COUNTERBALANCE a bottle of TGEL and a congealed TAPA on a puple drumstick. "It's not WORTHIT" he thinks, to even ask. No chance of a bird-filled TABLEHOP with Barry.

Barry: "IGOTYOU! I'd love a kneesup BARCRAWL, Stig, but  wait, me ATMCARD is lost and I'm proper skint"

Stig sighs, and urges Barry out the door and down the HALL. "Not to worry, all you need is cash"

Breezed right through today. We used to play the floor is lava all the time.

Not sure about the clue for HALL, but I did get it.  Took me a moment to grok A TO B.

What is going on this week? Monday it's a petting zoo of BABY animals. Tuesday, REESES PIECES. And today, THE FLOOR IS LAVA. I kind of hope the childhood nostalgia streak continues cuz I'm having fun! Like many others, I had HAuL before HALL. I guess the question mark is there because not all halls are long? I dunno. I'm glad someone else in the comments explained SST. My only remaining question is about BAR CRAWL. I'm trying to figure out what kind of bar... Oh. Wait. I guess it could be like a breakfast bar in a kitchen. Is there some other kind of bar in a house you could crawl on? Also, big thanks to @Sam Corbin for linking to the William Carlos Williams plums in the ice box meme. I had not seen it before. Some of the examples are priceless. For anyone who didn't read the column... https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2017/11/william-carlos-williams-icebox-plum-poem-is-now-twitter-meme.html

ATOB - that could be the title of my post today. It perfectly illustrates how confused I was by the bottom third of the puzzle. RIGA was a gimme but most of the other entries there I hopelessly struggled with, finally resorting to lookups of SST, ELO, WELTY, TED TALK, and TGEL.

AD ASTRA and ADOLPH emerged from crosses. I know the latter is just a name, in a way, but in this part of the world it only ever comes up in one context, accompanied by a look of disgsut.

I needed loads of crosses for THE FLOOR IS LAVA. I know the game from the internet only, where it came up in some memes. Of course we engaged in something similar as Polish kids in the 1980s, but the game never had a name.

And finally, that ATOB... I really tried to parse it once it emerged from crosses. I looked and looked at it and its clue... Nope. I needed the column to understand what I was seeing. I don't really get the connection between the clue and answer. To me, A to B is a description of the simplicity of a solution to a problem, which may be something completely different than it being short.

I don't get why CARD solves to WIT - could somebody please explain?

Despite it being mentioned in the column, I still don't understand why 'Long way to go?' solves to HALL. I'd appreciate an explanation of that, too, please.

Finally - not mowing one's lawn is one of the easiest ways to help the environment - especially insects - and water retention in the age of climate change. EYE SORE... That's 1950s thinking.

Got there eventually but the cultural chasm  today was deep

I'm mildly offended that the columnist reduces this theme to a "meme-inspiration". I played this game as a kid well before memes existed and the creator doesn't suggest that the meme is what inspired them.
I enjoyed learning the trivia about CHER, OSAKA and TED TALKs, and the puzzle overall.
I'm guessing I spent over half my solve time trying to come up with answers in the SW, which put me way over average.   The rest of the puzzle seemed pretty typical Wednesday difficulty.

A number of people have mentioned having trouble in the SW with not knowing Eudora WELTY as one of their problems. I'm here to thank her for getting me to change Erie, PA, which I was sure was a gimme, to the correct answer, YORK. Otherwise, I'd have been stuck in that corner quite a while.

As for the theme game, instead of THE FLOOR IS LAVA, my brother, sister and I played the floor is quicksand in the late 1960s. Sofa and chair cushions on the floor were the safe ways we traveled from furniture piece to furniture piece.

The constructor notes make very clear that the theme was not inspired by some random 2017 meme, but rather by the decades-old childhood game that meme was based on, so the first few paragraphs of the column don’t make sense…having never heard of the meme but having played the game countless times in the 80s, I was confused! (FWIW, we then just called it Hot Lava. But I am familiar with the more recent popular kids song The Floor Is Lava.)

THE FLOOR IS LAVA was one of the regular glimpses of a mysterious parallel universe that the NYT affords me. (As was TPED, though I now know that one.)
If I understand the activity correctly, it would have led to me spending the rest of the day confined to my room, at best. The same would apply to the current generation of children in my family.
So, for obvious reasons, the theme was no help today!

Although I'm one of the people who actually enjoyed AD ASTRA, I developed a mental blank about its title that held me up for a long time in the SW.

(I still don't get HALL, though it came easily enough on the crosses.)

Neat puzzle but like others, I have to concur that “the floor is lava” has been around for decades, at least. My brothers and I played it a lot, way back in the way back, of the very early ’60s.

Random thoughts:
•	Seems like a tight theme.  It’s one of those where commenters would be coming up with good answer alternatives, and it’s been crickets so far.  I’ve certainly tried and failed. Props to Eli on this!
•	After a lifetime of saying, “The end is nigh,” with this puzzle I can finally say, “The beginning is nigh.”

•	Speaking of [House with a long-unmowed lawn, e.g.], we have just such a house on our street.  The new owner has lived there several months and the front yard is getting jungle-y.  She's very nice, hasn’t mentioned it, and one has brought it up to her.  The neighbors have begun commenting.  Stay tuned.

While others are enjoying pleasant childhood memories from THE FLOOR IS LAVA, I'm having unpleasant flashbacks induced by PREFAB. I grew up in a post-war Arcon Mk V prefab housing scheme. While they could be erected in eight hours by a sufficiently large team, they generally took longer. They were so poorly insulated that the toilet cistern (which was mounted against an external wall) used to freeze solid during winter nights, and when the house was quiet you could hear the larger birds walking along the roof ridge. https://tinyurl.com/4jsyumpe The strange brick and corrugated-iron structure in the first image at the end of my link is an "Andershed". These were garden sheds built from some of the components of a wartime Anderson Shelter. The originals were cheap personal bomb shelters for people with gardens large enough to accommodate one. They required an excavation so that they were buried to roof level. When the war ended, the materials were repurposed to provide above-ground sheds---we had one behind our house, identical to the one in the picture.

The first Eudora Welty story I read was like opening a door and entering a world I hadn't known existed. I wanted there to be more stories, and there were. Her writing illuminates the extraordinariness of everyday life and you recognize the complexity we all share as human beings. They are sometimes funny, sometimes heartbreaking, more often a tangle of both. Long before the civil rights movement, Welty saw the Depression era in the same way, and recorded it in the photographs she took for the WPA before devoting her talent exclusively to writing. Take a look at these: https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/09/lens/eudora-welty-photos-mississippi.html If you don't know who she is, you've got a lot to look forward to.

Just checking in now and I'm pretty surprised about the HALL kerfuffle.  ELO has been an answer a whopping 256 times, mostly clued to the band, 6 times to Mr. Blue Sky.  When faced with E_O, any medium to long time solver has an excellent chance of guessing that it's ELO.

The clue for HALL is not wrong, it's pun.  Yes, you're supposed to think about "the long haul" but the answer relates to another type of [long way to go?] as indicated by the question mark.  Think of the long HALLways in a hotel.  Every HALL does not have to be long for the clue to work.

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight
They're pidgin English dating from the time of Chinese migrant workers in the USA.

By which I mean, early/mid 19th century.
There's nothing wrong with pidgins per se---they perform a useful function, and some languages, like Swahili, have evolved from pidgins.
Were these phrases originally used to mock the way Chinese people with limited English spoke? Probably.

There's a passage in one of the "Biggles" books that I rather treasure. Biggles addresses a Chinese man with the words "Speakee English?"
To which the man replies, in a weary English accent, "Not that sort."
@Rich  It seems to me that the word racist, whether used as a noun or an adjective, is fast becoming almost ubiquitous.

@Oikofuge

Pidgins aren't inherently racist.  They are simplified versions of languages designed to facilitate communication with people who don't understand much of the language.  When used with immigrants, they're useful bridges to understanding until the immigrant can learn enough of the new language to speak properly.

Phrases like NO CAN DO are only racist if they mock the people using them.  That depends on the specific situation; they are not inherently racist.

Tok Pisin, literally pidgin talk or pidgin language, is spoken by 5 million or so in New Guinea and is an official language there.  It is ironically no longer considered a pidgin, because it is now the native language of hundreds of thousands of people.  However, it developed as a pidgin originally, developing into a full-fledged language later.  It, like all pidgins, developed out of the need for diverse peoples to communicate with each other.  There's nothing inherently racist about it.

@Oikofuge et al.
"Since when has this become racist?"

I guess the real question is "when did this become *non*-racist?" And I'd argue that it has. Although I understand the etymology of the phrase, like Ms. Billie, I regularly use it, and hear it used, with nary a racial thought in my head. In fact, I have to *consciously* think "racially" to find it, well, racial. I expect most my audience has to do the same. Same with the counting rhyme "Eeny, meeny, miney, moe," which I learned with a phalangied Tiger; it was only as an adult I learned there was ever another version. (And we get those fill-worthy words all the time in the puzzle.)

And there is often a double standard at work--why is Br'er Rabbit considered racist, but Anansi not?

Of course, some people will go out looking for offense--I've seen people complaining about NIP being used as an entry, even when it was clued as [something a small dog might do], and even though n-i-p was an outdated pejorative when I was a kid; I bet a lot of younger wordplayers will have to look it up to see what I'm even talking about.

Contentious post--I hope it stays.
